title: The Evil of the Daleks
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor in reflective mood: 'I am not a student of human nature. I am a professor of a much wider academy of which human nature is merely a part.'
dialogue_disasters: Dalek dialogue such as 'You will not feed the flying pests outside' and 'Dizzy Doctor'.
Maxtible's terrible grammar: 'Everything you see here was created by us two.'
goofs: In episode two, part of a camera appears as the Dalek questions Victoria.
The massed Daleks of the final battle are obviously toys.
Marius Goring calls Waterfield 'Whitefield' and 'Skaro Skarov'.

continuity_notes.name: Dalek Emperor
continuity_notes.description: Leader of the Daleks, controlling the other Daleks in this story.

continuity_notes.name: Dalek Group Mind
continuity_notes.description: The collective consciousness of the Daleks, unable to cope with questions to orders.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord protagonist, described as 'more than human' by the Daleks due to time travel.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space travel machine, believed by the Doctor to be potentially destructible by Daleks.

roots: Poe ('The Facts in the Case of M. Valdemar')
The Beatles' Paperback Writer and other records from July 1966

locations.name: London
locations.description: Capital city of England, setting for parts of the story
locations.current_status: Time periods: 20 July 1966 and 2 June 1866 onwards

untold_adventures: The Doctor states that he watched the Charge of the Light Brigade ('magnificent folly').
qv: The First History of the Daleks
additional_notes: The story was designed to kill off the Daleks with a big bang. The Doctor pushes a Dalek over a cliff in episode seven. The Daleks measure weight in ounces and believe time travel has made the Doctor 'more than human', suggesting they don't know about Time Lords at this point.
bottom_line: A grandiose production which papers over its scientifically implausible aspects with a confident swagger.
